div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,532] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, JUNE 29, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate Steamers do not proceed at Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday attached to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

*Sleeping and Dining Cars. - During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays, and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays, and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary night trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers.

div.head: BELLA VISTA HOTEL
div.p: This excellent hotel, which includes also a hydropathic establishment, is situated in the healthiest part of modern Jaffa, close to the sea, and commands a magnificent view of the old town. It supplies every home comfort, has a large salon and airy bedrooms, promenade, and a cuisine suited to all tastes. It is within easy walking distance of the station and quay. Moderate charges.

The Hydropathic Department, which is furnished with all necessary baths and electrical apparatus, is under the care of a skillful diplomed physician, whose effacious treatments have already rendered invaluable help to many sufferers.

FRIDAY, JUNE 29, 1906.

div.head: JUDGES UNDER JUDGMENT
div.p: The unseating of a member of Parliament must, in most circumstances, be regarded as regrettable, being, as it generally is, the consequence of an infringement of our boasted purity of elections. The unseating of Mr. Agar Robartes, the Liberal member for Bodmin, is not nearly so serious a matter, however, as in the remarks made by Mr. Justice Grantham in delivering judgment, says the "Evening Standard and St. James Gazette"

With Mr. Justice Grantham in his present position we have great sympathy. A charge of the greatest gravest gravity - to use his own words - is hanging over his head. He is to be accused by Mr. Swift MacNeil in the House of Commons of a dereliction of duty so gross that, if the charge were substantiated, he could hardly affront his own honour by remaining on the Bench. The Government have not noly granted a day for Mr. MacNeill's motion of censure, but have promised to name that day as soon as possible. In such circumstances we can hardly hope that Mr. MacNeill will find himself in a minority of one. Doubtless he will find supporters in the lobby, as he has found them in the House supporters who, looking at all things from a party standpoint, are unable to conceive that a judge can keep an impartial mind under political strain. But we trust and believe that a majority of the House will be assured of Mr. Justice Grantham's honesty as we are ourselves; and it must be remembered that when the question has been cleared of its official trappings it is his honesty, not his judgment, which is attacked.

Before now we ourselves (continues our contemporary), while never doubting his high sincerity, have had occasion to attack Mr. Justic Grantham's judgment. It has been subject, like that of other judges, to lapses, and the effect of comparatively small errors has been emphasised by Mr. Justice Grantham's incurable habit of "speaking out."

The faculty of saying what he thinks bluntly and straightforwardly is often most useful to a judge, but it must be used very carefully if it is not to land the possessor in difficulty. Mr. Justice Grantham spoke out last week at a time when he would have done far better to keep his mouth closed. He had, he declared in a voice broken by emotion, been unfairly treated by the Government. The charge of partisanship was absolutely without foundtion. The time had arrived which was foreshadowed by the late Chief Justice Cockburn, when bitter party politicians would abuse judges for not giving judgment in accordance with their political wishes. And so on, ad nauseam.

Mr. Justice Lawrence, who also has the facult of speaking out but uses it with more discretion, was sorry that his brother Grantham had made any allusion to the charge against him. For himself, he had his own conscience to consider, not that of political parties, and for any abuse that might be lavished on him he did not care.
It can scarcely be doubted which is the more correct attitue for a judge to assume. He has his own conscience to consider, and, so long as he satisfies that, he must not care for outside criticism.

Indeed, the dignity of the Bench will be imperilled if its occupants should follow the precedent of Mr. Justice Grantham and begin, in season and out of season, to defend themselves against their crtics. At present they enjoy a wonderful immunity from public censure. The Bar may have its private opinion of the fitness of certain judges for their high office. The members of the Bar may be disposed to think - they would not be mortal if they refrained - that the judge has not grasped their point of view. but so far as the great public is concerned the opinion held of the Bench is so firm that crticism may be said to be almost non-existent. We all believe the judges try to do their duty, and recognising that they are but men, we are not inclined to call them to judgment for their every action.

To this happy state of things the judges themselves have contributed by a fine aptitude for keeping silence. It is largely because they do not invite criticism that they rarely suffer it. Secure in their own integrity, they impose confidence on the public mind. How long will this implicit confidence continue if the example of Mr. Justice Grantham be followed? We could give it no extended lease on such conditions. A hankering for self-defence, a yielding to the natural but resistible temptation of speaking out on behalf of their own reputation, is calculated to do more harm to the dignity of the Bench than many years' indulgence in the offensive and futile practice of squandering feable jokes. The judge who jokes may save himself. He who is eternally on the defensive is doomed to lose half his strength.

Let us hope Mr. Justice Grantham will follow the advice he has given to many prisoners, and not do it again. We trust there is no danger of his judicial brethren following in his footsteps, or of the House of Commons failing to let him see that his honour and reputation are safe in the hands of a body of English gentlemen.

div.head: Mounted Infantry.
div.p: The Mounted Infantry, whose present march from Cairo to Alexandria will prove memorable, is expected to reach Alexandria on Sunday next.

div.head: Release of Prisoner
div.p: We hear that Hassan Bey Wassif, ex Moudir of Girgeh, will be released from prison on Saturday, his health having suffered from his confinement. The edict authorising his release has already been issued.

div.head: Urbanora.
div.p: A new programme is announced for tonight at the Urbanora cinematograph. Among the new films will be that representing the Siege of Port Arthur, which is said to be the longest film in existence.

div.head: Terrible Bathing Tragedy.
div.p: A terrible accident is reported from Talha. A little girl, while bathing, was carried away by the current. Her brother, a child of nine years of age, attempted to rescue her and was swept down the stream, and two men who plunged in a gallant attempt to save the children were also drowned.

div.head: Rubattino Steamer Delayed
div.p: The Florio-Rubattino S.S. Bosforo left for Benghazi this morning to aid in the salvage of the S.S. Drepano, which has gone ashore in those parts, and therefore the Bosforo's departure of the 1st July for Brindisi, Bari, Ancona, and Venice has been postponed until her return.

div.head: Theft from Office.
div.p: The cashier of Messrs. B. Aghion, Adib-street, Alexandria, forgot to look up a bag containing 300 sovereigns in the safe on Wednesday night and discovered yesterday that the bag was msising. After questioning the servants he called in the Mamour el Kism and a search resulted in the discovery of the bag which still contained £203, in the gas meter. One of the three Berberin had already taken his share of the swag (less three pounds) and all will shortly appeaar before the Parquet.

div.head: Maltese Benevolent Society.
div.p: A grand gala performance of the ever-popular "musical-play". The Geisha will be given the Alhambra Theatre on Wednesday next, 4th proxo., in aid of the funds of the Alexandria Maltese Benevolent Society. The performance will be under the distinguised patronage of Mr. E.B. Gould, H.B.M's Consul General, and H.E. the governor has promised to honour it with his presence. We feel sure that the performance will be both a financial and artistic success. The Lombardo company has decidedly scored with the Italian version of Mr. Sidney Jones's pretty play, and the object for which this performance has been organised ought to prove an additional attraction. We may say that The Geisha will be produced this evening.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. H.J.L. Beadnell, the Corporation of Western Egypt's manager in the Oases, in a note on land in Northern Kharga, says: The cultivable areas comprise alluvial covered tracts of two distinct qualities: (1) first class heavy loam land; (2) lighter sandy land. Where these have been broken up and cultivated before - even so far back as Roman times - excellent crops can be raised the first year. A field of wheat raised on the corporation's property at El Der during the past winter was grown on soil which had lain fallow for at least one thousand five hundred years, and which was, up to the time of sowing, bare desert, absolutely devoid of vegetation of any kind. No manure whatever was used, owing to lack of transport at the time. The ground on which this crow was raised is typical of much of the land in this area, and is in no way a selected plot. The area - comprising about 4000 acres - on which boring operations are now being carried out is, for the most part, covered with a thick deposit of alluvial sandy clay or loam, overlying porous sandstones; the conditions are, in fact, ideal for agriculture. The greater part of these lands has never before been under cultivation, and, being dry, hard and lacking in humus, will probably require on an average three years cultivation to bring them into first-rate condition. "Our first season's operations," Mr. Beadnell goes on to say, "show however, that good crops can be raised even from the first sowing, if the land is dressed with only a very moderate amount of farmyard manure. I have no hesitation in saying that, provided with a sufficient water supply for irrigation, these lands will after two or three years cultivation, grow crops of rice, barley, wheat, and probably cotton, equal to any in Egypt and, with facilities for the transport of produce by railway to the Nile Valley, should be easily disposed of at remunerative figures. Land of similar quality in the Nile Valley is worth at the present time upwards of £70 an acre, and prices seem likely to rise still higher. There is every reason to suppose, therefore, that when the time comes for selling it will be easy to dispose of our best class of land at between £30 and £40 an acre, and that of lighter quality at about half that figure. The results obtained during the past year have confirmed my original opinion of the potential value of the lands of Norhtern Kharga from an agricultural point of view. I may mention, also, that a well known Anglo-Egyptian, who visited the Oasis last January, informed me that our first crops were much better than those he had obtained after three years' cultivation on lands similarly reclaimed in the Fayoum; that land he disposed of at £30 an acre and over, and it is now worth probably double that figure."

div.head: BIRTHDAY HONOURS.
LOCAL RECIPIENTS.
div.p: Among the recipients of Birthday Honours are Lord Cromer, who has been appointed to the Order of Merit, and Mr. P.W. Machell and Lieut. Col. Edgar Edwin Bernard, Financial Secretary to the Sudan Government, both of whom have been made C.M.G.'s.
King's Birthday Honours. Companions of the Order of St. Michael and St. George Egypt, Captain Machell; Sudan, Colonel Bernard. (Reuter)

div.head: THE YEMEN REVOLT.
JEWISH REFUGEES AT SUEZ.
div.p: A considerable number of Jews are arriving at Suez weekly from Aden. These people are refugees from Sana and other Arabian towns, which they were compelled to abandon owing to the hardships and the revolt.
Some of them report that the insurgents are holding most of the positions, and are armed with the latest rifles.

div.head: FRONTIER COMMISSION
div.p: The Frontier Commission has arrived at El Rafah, where its members will remain three days before leaving for El Ariah. We hear that the maps drawn up by the surveyors are not likely to be completely before July 8.

div.head: Al AZHAR.
div.p: In consequence of recent incidents at Al Azhar, the following regulations will be strictly applied in the case of visitors to the University.

Every visitor must be furnished with a permit of entry which will be viséed at the office of a special official appointed to supervise all visits. A special entrance will be set apart for visitors, who will be accompanied by persons selected by the officials in charge and will not be permitted to visit the University on Fridays. On all other days of the week visits will be permitted between 9 a.m. and noon and between 3 p.m. and 5 p.m. Cameras and sketchboards are strictly forbidden.

We should like to express our appreciation of these regulations and especially of the prohibition of kodaks and the like. Many of the stricter Moslems of the University have a strong aversion, based on Mohamed's prohibition of the representation of living beings, to being photograhped or sketched by chance visitors, especially by ladies, and we consider that their conscientious objections deserve the resepct of members of another faith.

div.head: BISHOP POTTER ON EGYPT.
div.p: It will be remembered that Bishop Potter, at the recent dinner of the Pilgrim Society in London, made the statement that "in the streets of Cairo the American Eagle held its tail between its legs."
Asked by an American reporter what he meant by that, he replied:
"I meant that the only time I ever saw our flag there was when it was used on posters in the street for advertising purposes."

Bishop and Mrs. Potter spent the winter in Egypt and they went as far up the Nile as the First Cataract. He said that in Nubia he had an opportunity to study the negro on his native heath. He said that in many of them mental progress never got beyond a certain point, but that there were others who were capable of great development intellectually.

"I found a great many changes on the face of Egypt since I visited that country 20 years ago," said the bishop, "but no change in the minds of the people. Lord Cromer said to me : 'You can change the face of the land by railroads and canals and irrigation, and you can lift physical conditions by better government, but you cannot change the mind of the Oriental in a quarter of a century. He will still think orientally.' This is a basic fact which we have to recognize in all our dealings with the Orientals."

div.head: EXPIATION.
LAST ACT IN DENISHWAI DRAMA.
EXECUTION OF SENTENCES.
THE SCENE AT DENISHWAI.
div.p: I have spent the greater part of today at the village of Denishwai, where, it was my lot to witness the carrying out of the death sentences passed on the four leaders of the attack on British officers and the flogging of seven others. As you know, eight of the prisoners were sentenced to fifty lashes, but it will be remembered that in my letter of yesterday I mentioned that Said Suleiman Kheiralla (No. 15) had been seized with an epileptic fit, and it was certified by Dr. Nolan that the man was medically unfit to stand corporal punishment.

Arriving at Batanoun shortly before ten o'clock I went along the road which the officers concerned had traversed, but this time the usually quiet road was thronged with those who were on their way to see the sentences carried out. The distance is about eight miles and at frequent intervals one met ghaffirs, not asleep or conversing with the fellaheen, as is their wont, but erect and alert, saluting the officials who passed.

After crossing the Bagourieh Canal in a ferry I came across the troops who were to escort the prisoners to Denishwai later in the day. Next, Sersina was passed and the police outpost of Shohoda, full of shawishes charged with guarding those who were about to receive their sentences. This villagers appeared strangely inactive and curious, while groups of women were collected to watch those on their way to Denishwai passing by. Further along the road crowds were sheltering under the trees, talking no doubt of this dreadful affair and its consequences, and staring at the passers by with great interest. The nearer one drew to Denishwai, the greater the numbers of onlookers, police, and ghaffirs.

Presently, a black wooden scaffolding was sighted, the village of Denishwai was plainly discernible, and we knew that we were reaching the scene of the attack Fellaheen were collected in immense groups at some distance from the scaffolding and mounted police were riding round every now and then to keep them away. But, these crowds were not formed by the villagers of Denishwai but by the hundreds who had collected from many parts of Menoufieh, for the former were confined within the bounds of the village by a cordon of police.

The gallows and the stand to which those about to be flogged were to be tied were within a large area which was roped round. They were almost on the very scene of the attack made on the party of officers on the 13th inst. Outside this area was the tent for the prisoners and another for the preparation of the four dead bodies for burial. Mr. Machell was on the scene with Mahmoud Pacha Shoucri, Moudir of Menoufieh, and Mr. Moberley was directing the erection of the gallows and other details.

At one o'clock the prisoners arrived accompanied by police and the British troops. Chained, handcuffed, and bound to each other by connecting anklets, the four who were sentenced to death were seated on a cart preceded by mounted police with Egyptian foot police on either side, and next came the cart bearinig the seven who were about to be flogged, while behind were several detachments of mounted British troops. The prisoners were escorted to the tent by Egyptian police, and the British troops formed a square round the area in which the punishment were to be given.

At half past one Hassan Ali Mahfouz was summoned and was brought before the Moudir by an escort of police. His sentence was read out and he was bade to say his final prayer, whereupon he exclaimed in a loud voice. "There is but one God and Mohamed is his prophet;" he was then pinioned and taken to the scaffold. Before the noose was tigtened round his neck he exclaimed, "May God ruin the houses of Mohamed Shedli (son of the omdeh), Mohamed Omar, and Ahmed Said," all of whom had given evidence against him. the trap door was opened, and the body fell through and hung until Ibrahim Hassan Assissi and Mohamed Mustapha Mahfouz had been flogged with fifty lashes previous to receiving one year's imprisonment. The flogging was received by all the seven prisoners with loud goans, and so severe was it, that Ibrahim Hassan Assissi exclaimed after three or four lashes that he would rather be hanged than flogged.

In such a manner the sentences were carried out; one man was hanged and left with his neck in the noose until two had been flogged, and then the next of the condemned suffered the extreme penalty. Every now and then a loud wail from the women came from the village, but save for this all was strangely quiet. It must be said that the four prisoners went to the scaffold expressing faith in their God and the scaffold expressing faith in their God and [NR] offered the slightest resistance. The dreadful imprecation uttered by Hassan Mahfouz was the only remarkable occurrence.

A section of the native Press is loud in its attacks on Ibrahim Bey Helbawi, whom it accuses of a violent bias against the fellaheen brought up for trial in the Denishwai case. Why the Public Prosecutor should be criticised for having done his best for the prosecution, and for having made a very eloquent speech demanding the infliction of severe punishment on the guilty parties, we cannot understand. Counsel for the prosecution is entitled, and indeed bound, to make the very best of his case. Perhaps the fact that Ibrahim Bey Helbawi is of fellah origin and has in the past shown sympathy with part of the Nationalist programme has encouraged his critics to rebuke him for refusing to subordinate his conscience to his political and racial leanings.

div.head: TEACHING PROFESSION.
PROMISING CAREER FOR EGYPTIANS.
div.p: The following notice to holders of the Secondary Education Certificate has been issued by the Ministry of Education :-

The Khedivial Training College, 55 Darb e Gamamiz, Cairo, invites applications from students who have obtained the Secondary Education, Certificate and are desirous of qualifying for the teaching profession.

The new course of training for teachers of English and subjects taught in English which it is proposed to institute in October next in connection with the above College will extend over two years, and will include a more advanced study of the Arabic and English languages and their literatures, mathematics, history, geography, etc., than that prescribed in the Secondary Course of Study, together with theoretical and practical instruction in the Science and Art of Teaching. The course of study will rank on the same level as the Courses of the other Higher Colleges. (Medicine, Law and Engineeering) under the Ministry of Education, and the students who pass the Final Examination of the College and serve satisfactorily for one year on probation as teachers under the Ministry of Education will receive a Diploma in Teaching, which will be recognised by Government in its regulations concerning pay and appointments as equivalent to the Diplomas of the other Higher Colleges.

Subject to satisfactory work and conduct, each student of the Class of the First Year in the College will receive a student's allowance of L.E. 3 per mensem, and each student of the Class of the Second Year a student's allowance of L.E. 4 per mensem.

The Ministry of Education hopes through the Course of Training which is about to be instituted to provide teachers qualified for appointment in Secondary as well as Primary Schools. With this object in view, every year at least two of teh students who show most promise of developing into successful Headmasters and Secondary Teachers will be selected, subject to medical fitness, to continue their education and training, at the entire cost of Government, for a further period of two or three years in one of the best Training Colleges in England. On their return to Egypt, such students will be appointed on the permanent staff of the Ministry of Education, at an initial salary of L.E. 12 per mensem (Grade L.E. 12-16), and will subsequently receive preferential consideration in promotion to a higher rate of pay and in appointments as Headmaster, Secondary Teacher, etc.

The stuents who are not sent by Government to England for supplementary training on passing the Final Examination will be forthwith appointed as teachers on probation on the permanent staff of the Ministry of Education. During their year's service on probation, which is necessary to qualify for the Diploma, they will receive a provisional salary of L.E. 7 per mensem. On obtaining the Diploma, if accepted by the Medical Board, they will be confirmed in their appointment under Government and placed in the grade of L.E. 12-16, at an initial salary of L.E. 12 per mensem. Students who have obtained the Diploma in Teaching will be considered eligible for appointments as Headmaster, etc., even although owing to medical or other reasaons they have not been sent by Government to England to supplement their training.

As regards, subsequent professional prospects, it may be stated that the Headmastership of a Government Primary School at present generally carries with it a salary of L.E. 24-32 per mensem. Headmasters in Government Secondary Schools are paid at the rate of L.E. 600-800 per annum. In several both of the Primary and the Secondary Schools free residential quarters for the Headmaster are further provided. A number of grades of L.E. 16-20 have also been established for teachers in Primary Schools. Other opportunities of promotion are under consideration.

It may therefore be stated that the teaching profession, besides being highly honourable as contributing in an important degree to the development and progress of the country, now offers to the earnest Egyptian student and worker a remunerative and satisfactory career. The course of studey in the Khedivial Training College can therefore be recommended with confidence.

Applicants for admission to the College must be of Egyptian nationality and must have obtained the Secondary Education Certificiate with English as the principal language during the last four years. Such candidates as have not been in attendance at a Government School during the past school year must further produce a certificate of good character from some reliable person to whom they are personally known.

div.head: NILE GAUGE READINGS.
div.p: Owing to the absence of our Cairo Correspondent at Denishwai we have been unable to publish the Nile gauge readings during the past week. They will be resumed on Monday next and will thereafter appear daily.
The following are the figures for the 26th inst.:-
On the 27th inst. the Assouan gauge registered 2 pics, 4 kirats; the Halfa gauge 1m.69, and Rodah Island 11 pics, 5 kirats.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM
MORE INTRIGUES AT STAMBOUL.
div.p: From a remarkable message sent from Constantinople by a correspondent of the "Telegraph" it appears that the Sultan's advisers who were responsible for the Tabah affair are now exercising their influence in other directions in support of the pan-Islamic movement.

These Arab Shaikhs, who, according to the correspondent, were entirely to blame for the recent frontier trouble, and not Izzet Pacha, represent tribes scattered about North Africa, and are always men of high religious standing. The result is that they are always well received at the Palace, and the Sultan, as Caliph, must pay some attention to their arguments. What their object is it is not quite clear, but it is apparently working in connection with the pan-Islamic movement, and for that reason alone is bound to get support from the Sultan. Some people who have tried to get at the bottom of the matter believe that it is really and truly the outcome of a coalition of the Arab tribes; to secure the Sultan's help, by using the pan-Islamic movement as an instrument, to bring about quarrels between the Powers at present interested in North Africa, and, in the resulting confusion, to set up an Arab State or confederacy, with a Caliph of their own. If this is true, it is plain that the first thing to happen would be that the SUltan would be brought into conflict with the Powers, and would finally get the worst of it. In the second place, once the Arab State was founded, their first objective would be supported by the already rebellious tribes. Of course, it is most unlikely that they would ever come to that point, and only could do so in the event of their having succeeded in bringing about an open rupture between some of the European Powers.

I have all along, spoken of the Sultan, because all these matters are worked direct from the Palace, the Porte being left entirely in ignorance until a difficulty arises, and then everything is laid on the shoulders of the Porte, which has to find some means of arranging the matter.

This Arab party has no connection with the Senoussi, who keep themsevles apart from all others, and regard the Turks as heretics, and whose chief will never receive the Sultan's envoys, always moving off into the Desert when they appear - in fact, showing very plainly that they will have "no truck" with him at any price. The sheikhs argument with the Sultan are that they are simply acting in a defensive manner, to prevent the Empire from being encroached upon. They only urge the Sultan to occupy certain places, not with a view to the conquest of new territory, but because they are now unoccupied, and in order to prevent them being occupied by others. Thus the Sultan's action would only tend to preserve the status quo. With these wily arguments they have persuaded the Sultan to order expeditions into the hinterland of Tripoli, with the object of occupying several different places. They also intend making another attempt to advnace in the direction of Soloum, which will bring them again into conflict with the English and Egyptians. The other places mentioned are Bilma and Moa, in the district of Kanem, and Barrowa and Jalo, S. of Barce. These will bring them into conflict with the French, who claim that they come under their sphere of influence. I believe they are not actually occupied by the French, but once or twice a year they are visited by dromedary patrolling parties to show the flag. Anyhow, the situation is interesting, and the developments require careful watching. Unfortunately, everything is kept so secret that it is impossible to obtain more than the barest outline. The installation of wireless telegraphy between Tripoli and Asia Minor is most significant, as now direct communication can be made between Constantinople and Tripoli.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Persian (Westcott and Laurance Line) left Malta yesterday and is due here next Sunday with general cargo from Antwerp and London.
The Moss linear Rameses sailed yesterday afternoon from Malta, and is due here on Monday morning with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner Seti arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: Marché toujours calme avec des affaires très clairsemées; la réalisation de fin de mois, assez chargée, fait fléchir quelques valeurs, les privilégiées. Tramways et la Banco di Roma sont seules en hausse.
L'Agricole est soutenue à 9 5/8.
La National Bank a'affaiblit de 1/8 à 25 3/8.
Les Tramways d'Alexandrie avancent de 1 franc à 195.
Les Obligations Crédit Foncier Egyptien restent à leurs cours précédents.
La Cassa di Sconto a donue lieu à quelques affaires; apres avoir attaint 215 en cours de séance elle clôture à 214 1/2 en hausse de 1 fr. 50 sur hier.
La Delta Land recule de 1/16 à 3 5/8 acheteurs.
Les Trust les Estates et le Comptoir financier sont stationnaires.
La Banque d'Orient perd 0 fr. 25 à 132 1/2.
Les autres valuers n'éprouvent aucun changement on à peu près.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mr. Langley, Inspector of the 1st Circle of Irrigation, has been appointed Inspector General of Irrigation for Upper Egypt, with a salary of L.E. 1,400 per annum. Our hearty congratulations.
M. and Mme Luzzatto left the Savoy Hotel, London, last week, to sail for America.
Captain C.H. Palmer, 4th Battalion Worcestershire Regiment, left Alexandria for Port Said yesterday, to embark on the City of Athens for passage to Malta.

Yesterday, at the British Consulate, Alexandria, before Mr. E.B. Gould, I.S.O., Consul General, the civil marriage of Mr. A.M. General, the civil marriage of Mr. A.M. Tennant, of the Waterworks, and Miss Annie Bass took place, the contract being signed and witnessed by Miss Tennant, Mr. T. Bent, and Mr. R. Williams. The party afterwards proceeded to St. Mark's Chruch, where the religious ceremony took place, Rev. R.T. Rynd, B.A., officiating. In the church a good many members of the British community witnessed the interesting ceremony, after which the happy pair started through a shower of rose leaves and the blessings of their friends on their way to the hills of Syria for their honeymoon.

div.head: SKYE MEETING.
div.p: The July Skye Meeting of the Alexandria Sporting Club will take place on the 14th proxo. Entires will close at 4 p.m. on the 6th proxo, and will be published on the 9th proxo.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: Played on Wednesdy on the A.C.C. ground. The scratch XI. won the toss and after two wickets had fallen quickly R.B. Maclean hit up 37. Macaulay and Graves, both of whom had a little luck to start with, then added a hundred, Macaulay being sixth out for a very freely hit 89, which included two fives and sixteen fours. Dawson and Dealtry hit freely and the innings closed for 253. Blythman and Henley bowled well on the whole. The E.T.C. XI started badly, losing Harrison at 5, but with three down for 39, Henley and Cheesman came to the rescue and scoring very freely, "remained" undefeated till stumps were drawn. Cheesman had some luck, but his innings was very creditable, and Henly, batting far more freely than usual, played very attractive cricket.

div.head: LA POSTE DU CAIRE
div.p: D'un de nos confrères du Caire.

Le service le plus mal fait du pavs et dont tout le monde ne cesse de se plaindre, c'est bien celui de la poste. Tous mes collegues, ont présenté vainement la défense de la population contre les procédés déploables de cette administration. A leurs protestations, je joins la mienne aujourd'hui, malgré la triste certitude que je ressens, de precher... dans le désert.

Il n'est pire sourd que celui qui ne veut entendre. ne trouvez-vous pas, amis lecteurs, que ca proverbe a'applique avec justesse à nos pouvoirs publics que semblent se désintéresser complètement de toutes nos recriminations contre la poste?
Il serait temps enfin de faire cesser des abus dont la population est plus que lasse et que la presse a toujours vigoureusement b'âmés.

Nos intérêts les plus sérieux sont compromis, nos affaires manquées, nos liens sociaux distendus, nos familles déunies, mille antres conséquences désastreuses résultent souvent de l'incurie de la poste. Je ne crois pas que nulle part au monde, elle suit aussi mal faite qu'au Caire. Tous les jours, il a'y passe de faits inouis du genre de celui que je vais vous citer et dont je connais personnellement le témoin oculaire:
Quelqu'un va faire recommander une lettre pour un grand port de l'Afrique du Sud, port achiconnu, car les grands paquebots Marseille Australie y font escale.

Ce port u'ayant pas d'homonyme, l'expéditeur avait supposé que son seul mom suffrsait sur l'enveloppe avec la mention "Via Aden". Un élève de sixième en France aurait compris la chose, mais le petits employé de notre capitale dit su Monsieur ahuri: Oui, je sais c'est pour l'Allemagne!!! Quand et comment, pourra t'on faire comprende, aux employés de la poste que les correspondances "via Aden" doivent être expédiées au Sud par Suez et celles via Alexandrie au Nord?

Je connais des personnes que sont allees se plaindre du retard de leurs lettres pour le Su-Africain a qui de droit, mais ce "qui de droit" n'a pas empeche que leurs corrspondances adressees au Cap on a Natal ne continuent a etre expediees d'abord en Europe, d'ou elles sont ensuite re expediees; ce qui fait qu'une lettre pour Mozambique ou Madagascar n'y parvient qu'apres un voyage de deux mois. C'est incroyable, mais reel.

Les postes constituent en Egypte une source precieuse de revenus pour l'Etat, la plus riche de toutes peut etre et ses recettes ont augmente en remarquable proportion, ces dernieres aunees. Cependant cette administration paye si peu, ou plutot si mal, ses employes, quil serait exagere de pretendre rencontrer parmi eux des connaissances georgraphiques assez etendues.

Mais ce n'est pas l'ignorance du personnel de notre poste qui adresse en Chine les plis a destination du Chili, qui cause le pire de nos ennuis. Oersonne n'a le droit de se plaindre du retard des lettres, si elles finissent tout de meme par arriver.

Ce qui mecontente tout le monde, ce sont les lettres qui n'arrivent jamais a l'instar de ces rayons partis d'astres si eloignes qui'ils n'atteindront jamais notre astre terrestre. Voila l'enigme que nous refusons d'admettre parce qu'inexplicable.

Comment comprendre en effet, qu'une missive expediee du Caire au Caire ne parvienne jamais a son destinataire et que tel cas se reproduise tous les jours? Je ne parlerai pas des cartes postales qui tentent tout naturelleement les amateurs collectionneurs; une belle carte est inevitablement destinee a etre egaree, mais les lettres la correspondance serieuse, indispensable; ce depot sacre que nous conflions au service des Postes avec notre fortune, notre tranquillite l'honneur de nos familles, notre existence meme, quelles mesures prend cette administration pour nous en assureer la propriete et la secret?

N'est ce pas inadmissible que ce service continue a waiter le public d'une maniere aussi indecente? La patience a des bornes et il y a longtemps que la notre est a bout. Si un commissionnaire a qui l'on confiait une lettre pour une maison quelconque de la vile avec paiement de sa course, ne remplissait pas fidelement sa mission, on le ferait arreter et condamner probablement, reprimander a coup sur.
La Poste seule a doncile droit draconien de faire disparaitre les correspondances qui lui sont confiees?
Poser la qustion, c'est la resoudre.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny.
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres reste toujours invarié à 3 1/4 pour cent.

Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de non moins de 5/8 de livre à 80 1/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 104 3/4, de même que la National Bank à 25 5/8, la Daira à 17 1/8 et la Delta Light à 12.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Fonciér Egyptien a perdu 1 franc à 771. La Banque d'Athène est demeurée inchangée à 154.
Ici, le marché des valeurs a été, aujourd'hui, moins animé, moins actif qu'hier. Toutefois, les dispositions ne sont pas mauvaises, bien que la fermeté ne se soit pas maintenue sur toute la ligne.

Pen d'afiaireè en National Bank, qui à couturé à 25 1/2-9/16. L'Agricolé s'est tenue à son prix d'hier, soit 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto s'est alourdie à 213 l'action ancienne, ainsi que la Banque d'Athènes à 154 et la Banque d'Orient à 131 1/2.
L'action Crédit Foncier a molli à 770 et là part de fondateur à 910.
L'action Immobilière a fléchi à 366, l'Entreprise and Development à 11 15/16 et l'Agricole du Nil à 259; la part de fondateur a progressé, par contre, à 7 1/16.
Bonne demande en Improvements Corporation, qui a gagné 1/8 à 4 11/16 3/4.
L'action Entreprises Immobilière et Tra-vâux a'est raffermie à 4 1/16; la part de fondateur, très recherchée, a avancé à 70.
L'action Wardan Estate s'est inscrite à 6 et la,Nile Land à 13 1/2.
La part de fondateur Land Allotment a encore faibli à 110.
L'action de capital Eaux du Caire a fait 120-121; les Jouissances ont clôturé à 261 1/2 après avoir atteint 264.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich, délaissés, sont restés à 15 7/16 l'action anciene, et 15 3/8 la nouvelle. Les Baehler ont débuté à 5 23/32 pour finir à 5 21/32 11/16. Lee National ont progressé à 3 3/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été' ramenés à 3 13/16 et les Glymenopoulo à 1 9/16.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Londres, en date du 19 Juin, les lignes suivantes concernant la situation monétaire:

"Les conditions de l'argent se sont avanta-geaiement modifiées. L'encaisse de la Banque d'Angleterre s'est considérablement accru et la proportion de la réserve s'est élevée à plus de 47%. Le taux de l'escompte libre oscille entre 8 3/8 et 3 1/4 pour cent. La situation est donc, sans conteste, meilleure, bien que les disponibilités du marché aient à faire face à l'emprunt irlandais, annoncé pour le 7 Juillet; là tenue du cours du Consolidé anglais en est affectée. Le "Statist" ne prévoit pas une augmentation prochaine des disponibilités et s'attend même à des sorties considérables poor la fin du mois courant.

Le Stock Exchange jouit en ce moment d'un repos relatif; c'est l'effet de la morte saison. Là clientèle est devenue rare, et les mouvements des valeurs quelque peu somnolentes ont beaucoup perdu de leur étendue."
On annonce d'Athènes que L'assemblée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires de la Banque du Crédit Industriel de Grèce, tenue samedi passé, a voté à l'unanimité la fusion avec la Banque d'Athènes.
L'assemblée extraordinaire de la Banque d'Athènes, qui doit statuer sur le même objet; est fixée comme on sait; au samedi 7 Juillet prochain.

On assure que l'arrangement négocié entre le gouvernement et la Société des Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egyptè concernant l'achat par l'Etat des lignes de railways à voie étroite de cet té Société serait sur le point d'être conclu, au prix d'environ LE. 350,000.

Au dire d'un journal d'Alexandrie, un groupe financier, à la tête daquel se trouverait M. Scott, ancien directeur de la Compagnie d'assurance "The Gresham," se propose de former une Société anonyme de constructions economiques dont le siege social serait au Caire:

"Les acheteurs-locataires deviendraient pro priétaires au bout d'un certain nombrè d'années en payant un loyer comprenant l'amortis sement du prix de l'immeuble et une prime d'assurance, de sorte qu'en cas de mort leurs héritiers deviendraient par le fait propriétaires."

div.head: Egyptian Trust and Investment, Ltd.
62, London Wall, London, E.C.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the members of the above named Company will be held at the Registered Offices of hthe Company, 62 London Wall, n the City of London on Thursday the 12th day of July 1906 at 12 o'clock noon, when the subjoined Resolution Nod. 1, which was duly passed at an Extraordinary General MEeting held on the 26th day of June 1906 will be submitted for confirmation as a Special Resolution.
NOTICE IS ALSO GIVEN that the subjoined Resolution Nod. 2 will be submitted at the said Meeting for consideration and, if thought fit, passing as an Extraordinary Resolution.

1. That the Company be wound up voluntarily and that George Thomas Broadbridge the Secretary of the Company be and he is hereby appointed Liquidator for the purpose of such winding up, at a fee of £210 and expenses.

2. That this Meeting sanctions and directs the division by the Liquidator in specie among the Members of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited of the 60,000 fully paid shares of £4 each in the Building Lands of Egypt to which the Egyptian Trust and Invesetment Ltd. is entitled under or by virtue of the Agreement dated the 2nd day of June 1906 and made between the Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited of the one part and the Building Lands of Egypt of the other part, and so that each member of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited shall be entitled to three shares in the Building Lands of Egypt credited as fully paid hereinafter called new shares for every complete lot of ten shares held by him in the Egyptian Trust and investment limited hereinafter called the old shares and so that for every old share held by him in the Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited not amounting to a complete lot of ten shares such member shall be entitled to one enth of the net proceeds of sale of three new shares and the liquidator is hereby authorised to sell the surplus new shares after setting aside the number necesary to provide three new shares for each complete lot of ten old shares.
Dated this 29th day of June 1906.
By order of the Board,
GEO. T. BROADBRIDGE
Secretary

div.p: A sensation has been caused here by the Tsar having reprimanded General Gadon, commander of the famous Preobrajensky regiment, for failing to maintain discipline. This confirs the reports of the disaffection of the Guards Regiment. The first battalion has been ordered to aremote distract in Novgorod, where the first batch of Japanese prisoners were sent. (Reuter)
Martial law has been proclaimed in several districts in Russia, notably in the south, where agrarian disorders are increasing. (Reuters)
A battalion of the Preobrajensky regiment will be sent to a village in the Novgorod province owing to insubordination. (Havas)

During a reconnaissance in the Mapumulo district, a large force of Natalians encountered the rebels, who boldly charged despite artillery and Maxim fire; two kopjes were taken and sixty rebels killed, but the force retired on a thousand rebels endeavouring to outflank them. (Reuter).
Great Britain, France, and Italy have come to an agreement on the main points regarding Abyssinia. The maintenance of the status quo and the open door have been assured. (Reuter)
HOUSE OF COMMONS - The closure has been applied to Clause 4 of the Education Bill and adopted by 415 votes to 138. (Reuter)
Clause No. 4 of the Education Bill admittedly favours Catholics and Jews and therefore Churchmen are particularly resentful. (R.)
The traffic on the Manchester Ship Canal has been delayed a week owing to an accdient to a lock.
Earthquake shocks have been felt in Devon, Cornwall, Bristol, and Birmingham, but were slight.

div.head:
THE MILLIONAIRE MURDERER.
MRS. THAW NOT ARRESTED.

div.p: Mrs. Thaw has not been arrested. She visited her husband in prison, where the meeting was most affectionate. Eminent lawyers have been engaged to save Mr. Thaw, who is reportedly sane by alienists. (Reuter)
The Procurator General has concluded that Dreyfus is innocent.

div.head: THE MAKING OF MODERN EGYPT.
div.p: Modern Egypt has been fortunate in her historians. Instead of failing a prey to the wandering journalist or the armchair critic at home, she has had her history told by the men who helped to make it, Lord Milner, the late Sir Clinton Dawkins and Sir Eldon Gorst, and now Sir Auckland Colvin, who played a large part at the most critical time in her fortunes. Lord Milner's work was not a consecutive history, but a series of brilliant essays on the main Egyptian problems. Sir Auckland Colvin aims at following closely the order of events, "to tell, in popular terms, the story of the making of modern Egypt under British influence, from its ill-omened commencement, an throughout its early years of difficulty, doubting and disasters, to the triumphant close of the prolonged crisis." The nineteenth century in Egypt was a period of violent changes. The country, which had slumbered more or less since the Roman conquest, found itself suddenly drawn into the maelstrom of world politics. That barbarian of genius, Mohamed Aly, made of it a quasi-independent principality. Abbas and Said, his successors, were commonplace folk, but with Ismail commenced a saturnalia of extravagance. He found the public Debt four millions sterling. After sixteen years of recklessness he left it at one hundred millions,m and of his loans, so low had the credit of the country sunk, the net product barely amounted to half the liability. Bankruptcy was in the air, and with this danger came Arabi's rebellion. When Britain, after restoring order, commuted Arabi's death sentece to banishment, and thereby fatally weakened the Khedive's prestige, she took unwittingly a step which made impossible her retirement from the country. Henceforth her bayonet must guarantee order; and her hands make straight the tangle.

Britain's task in Egypt falls under three heads, the fight for solvency, the fight against the Mahdi and his successors for the security of the Nile, and the fight against internationalism. And the settlement of these problems falls under three main epochs financially. The first was from 1883 to 1889, when solvency was the only aim of the Administrations. From 1889 to 1896 the economy was still the main consideration, but much was done in the way of remitting the more burderonsome taxes. After 1896 came the period of construction, when Egypt with a full Treasaury could devote herself to reproductive expenditure, to making dams and building railways, and to revising her whole economic position. The first epoch was the period of trial, and it, too, has three distinct phases. the first was the time of Lord Dufferin's Mission, when hopes were still high, and the rottenness of the fabric had not been realised. The second began with Sir Evelyn Baring's arrival in 1883, and included the Gordon episode, the London Convention, and the International Settlement of 1885. It was a time when the most courageous miht well despair of any good issue from such chaos of perplexities. From 1885 to 1889 things were bad enough, but the course had been determined, and ti was possible for the watcher to see light behind the storm clouds. Sir Auckland Colvin is at his best in his narrative of these tangled years. He shows a scrupulous fairness towards men and institutions he is not in sympathy with. Nothing could be better, for example than his sketches of the chief Egyptian statesmen - Nubar, Riaz, and the rest - or his summary of the work of the Caisse. That Cerberus "is still to be found at his old post. But his teeth are drawn, his eyes are dim, his hearing is dull, and his limbs palsied. In a few years, when he dies, as he is doomed to die, of natural decay, the verdict on him will be that he was a faithful watchdog in his youth, a dog in the manger in later life, and in his closing years superfluous." He shows, too, the radical hopelessness of Gordon's scheme for the evacuation of the Sudan, in estimating which we are too prone to forget that Gordon wholly omitted one factor from his calculations, - the power of the Mahdi, which he only realised with the approach of death.

The second period was a time of prosaic hard work, during which Britain was fortunately concerned with other things, and left Egypt in the hands of the one man who understood her. But with the third period comes the era of expansion when the seed sown so laboriously begins to bear fruit. That fiscal emancipation must precede administrative imporvement was the first article of Lord Cromer's creed. The departments had to wait until the taxpayer had been relieved of the worst of his burdens. Lord Cromer's work is a fine example of the truth of the prover, festinalente. BEtween the years 1883 and 1889 he had the most heartbreaking task which has, perhaps, ever fallen to the lot of a British statemen. A weaker man would have broken down under the strain, a less wise man would have tried heroic remedies and forced the pace. But Lord Cromer never swerved either from his optimism or his patience, and the man who has faith in Time is rarely betrayed. The whole burden was on his shoulders, for the interventions of Britsh Cabinets were generally ill inspired, as in the extraordinary Drummond Wolff Mission. in Sir Auckland Colvins' pages may be read the tale of the progress first to solvency and then to prosperity of the solow reconquest of the Sudan, and of the gradual loosening of the shackles of internationalism which culminated in the AngloFrench agreement of 1904. The doom of internationalism was sounded when the Caisse, upheld by the Mixed Tribunals, refused to advance part of the cost of the Omdurman Campaign, and the British Government provided the money. The British Treasury does not part with public funds without some prospect of compensation. With the 1904 Agreement, Lord Cromer's steward ship was justified of its works. The history of Egypt and of the Sudan takes on a new character. The plateau has been reached, and progress is a smooth and rapid advance across a level country instead of the laborious struggle up the steeps. Of the man to whom this unparalleled result is due Sir Auckland Colvin has written in eloquent words. "He deserved success, and had ahcieved it; his name passes henceforth into that bright roll of his countrymen which derives its lustre in Eastern history, not from wars or bloodhsed, but from a higher and more noble title; from benefits conferred and contentment assured to alien peoples, through wise administration and the fruitful arts of peace."

Sir Auckland Colvin's work should take rank as the standard history of our labours in Egypt. Apart form his skillful arrangement of a large mass of materials , and the accuracy and lucidity of his exposition of intricate questions, it deserves to be read for its literary charm. Few men who have spent their lives in administration, more especially in financial administration, have attained to so admirable a style. Every chapter is enlivened with wit and picturesqueness of phrase, and he has a happy gift of classical reminiscence. He is as much alive to the romance of Egypt as the peripatetic French novelist who sees no other side. Among pages of grave politics it is pleasant to find such a sketch as that of old Zebehr, the slave dealer, whom Gordon asked for as his colleage :-

"As we leave behind us the darkness of those evil years, we take away, as a last impression, this is pleasing pastoral picture of Zebehr, retired perforce from the busy cares of manhunting, and spending the evening of his days in the fruitful sunshine of official favour; his sword turned into a pruning hook, and his later years employed as Candide would have had him employ them. We are reminded of that other gentle recluse at Edmonton, 'My name is Reitred Leisure; I am to be met in trim gardens; I grow into gentility perceptibly.'"

div.head: LORD MILNER HONOURED
div.p: At the Oxford Commemoration held in the Sheldonian Theatre in the historic City last week, the honorary degree of DCL was conferred upon Lord Milner.

His lordship was presented by Dr. Goudy, Regius Professor of Civil Law, as a true type and representative of Oxford culture. having received his school educaiton partly in Germany, he came to Oxford for his academic training, and obtained there the highest honours in the School of Literae Humaniores. In 1897 he was chosen to be Governor of Cape Colony, at a time of great unrest in South Africa. For his great services to the State he had been rewarded by a peerage and other well merited honours. However opinions might differ to the policy of the late war, no one could deny Lord Milner's strenuous and devoted labours on behalf of his country. He did not lose courage in the dark hours of adversity, and set an example to all his subordinates of unremitting attention to duty. Finally Lord Milner had not been unmindful of the muses, having written, among others, a valuable work on "England in Egypt".

Others receiving this honour were the Chinese Minister, Wang Tah-Sieh; the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, the Earl of Aberdeen, the Secretary for War, Mr. HAldane; Sir Horace Plunkett, and Sir John Madden, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, Victoria.

div.head: EMPIRE DAY RECOGNITION.
THE SUCCESS OF THE MOVEMENT.
div.p: It is stated by the Earl of Meath that the success which attended the Empire Day movement this year was far greater than even its most sanguine supporters ever expected. Some four millions of children have come under the influence of the movement, and an equal number of adults took part throughout the British dominions, actively or as spectators in the demonstration.

The Union Jack is the national flag, and the Earl contends that as the reminder of civic responsibility it should occupy a prominent position within and without every schoolhouse. In the United States and in our Colonies the flag is provided by the education authority, but as this is not the case in the Mother country, the Earl of Meath expresses the hope that the public will either by individual effort or by organized subscription raise funds in each parish sufficient to provide the local schools with a suitable flagstaff and large-sized Union Jack.

div.head: NEWS IN TIME OF WAR
SUGGESTED LEGISLATION
div.p: A conference of newspaper proprietors called for the purpose of considering the question of the regulation of the publication of news in time of war, was held last week at the Royal United Service Institution, Mr. A.F. Walter, of the "Times," presiding.

The chairman said the purpose of the meeting was to consider the question of controlling or restricting the publication of news during a state of war between England and any other Great Power. The main question was as to whether they were prepared to submit to a certain amount of control. In theory they were all for the country first and for their own private interests afterwards. In practice, it might easily happen that whether by inadvertence, or by too much zeal, or by error of judgment, any one of them mihgt do immense harm to the casue of the country and the Empire by the publication of news useful to the enemy. The concealment of important facts was, speaking generally, a policy of great advantage to our Japanese allies in the war with Russia, and in one instance was attended by consequences of the gravest moment. He was personally in favour of the proposed legislation provided that it went no further than their consent gave, and that its terms were clear and satisfactory.

Mr. Clifford explained that last November a letter of private inquiry was sent out to some 200 leading editors and proprietors. That letter was issued with the knowledge and consent, if not with the full apporvl, of the Committee of Imperial Defence. The Government considered that legislation was important, if only from the naval point of view.

He moved a resolution approving of the action taken by the Newspaper Society in appointing a Committee to confer with the Committee of Imperial Defence, and fully endorsing the priniple accepted by the subcommittee regarding the legislation, dealing with the dissemination of news in war time, and authorising the Newspaper Society to consider any Bill that might be drafted on the subject.

Mr. J.S.R. Phillips, in seconding, said that if he were a general in an army he should like to shoot all the newspaper men at the outset of a war, and he shoul dhave then done with one enemy, frequently the more serious.

Mr. Fabien Ware suggested that the proposed draft Bill shoul dbe submitted to the Government. He moved an amedment deleting the words "endorses the principles accepted by the subcommittee," and substituting in regard to the principles that should govern the legistlation.
Mr. Robert Donald seconded, and feared that under the resolution the newspapers would be cramped too much.
Mr. C. Arthur Pearson thought that the proposed exceptions were altogether too drastic.
Other members wante to know more about the Bill before committing themselves to the general principles.
The resolution as amended was finally adopted.

div.head: GREECE AND ROMANIA.
div.p: The cessation of diplomatic relations between Greece and Romania is no unfortunately definite. A White Book has just been published at Athens which shows that the Greek Government did all in its power to remain on good terms with Romania, but that it constatnly met with a spirit of intolerance on the part of Bucharest. Mr. Skouzes has explained in the Chamber the steps taken in the matter. Romania refused to enter into direct negotiations, and also to discuss the qeustion at St. Petersburg. Greece then offered to submit the question to the Peace Tribunal at the Hague, but he Bucharest Cabinet woul dnot hear of it. On the contrary, it took steps to bring about a rupture, and did nothing to prevent the assaults which frequently took place on Greek subjects in Romania. Moreover, the Parliament decided to impose heavy taxes on the subjects of those States which have no treaties of commerce with Roumania, a measure which was directly aimed at the Greek merchants settled in the country. The natural result of these injurious attacks was that negotiations were broken off, and it is difficult to understand why Romania, which under the rule of King Charles has always hitherto acted so wisely, should have deliberately taken up an attitude hostile to Greece over such a trumpery affair as that of the Kutzo-Vlachs. The two little kingdoms are the only make-weight of the Slavs in the Balkans, and they ought to tand shoulder to shoulder and not in opposition, a state of things which can only result in advantage to their opponents. ("Globe.")
